Replies.Reply: Everybody sometime in their life has met a real live hero.

They're not exactly a dime a dozen, but there's plenty of people who've done real great things. But hardly anyone has ever met a certified Legend, because most of them are dead before they get voted one.
In any language, in any country, in any world. The Sultan of Swat. The King of Clout. The Great Bambino.
There's never been anyone greater than The Babe. And when he called his famous full count homerun in the 1932 world series, he made sure he'd live forever.
would've happened. Weird thing was, before I moved to the neighborhood, I had no idea who he was. And he played a game I knew nothing about.

Fourteen years later, after The Babe was gone, there was another guy who had something to do with the legend getting made too. A guy who set a record that summer that was so awesome, some people still don't believe it.
I moved to the neighborhood about a month before school let out. I was from another state, and didn't have a single friend in a thousand miles.
Everyone but the Timmons twins lived on my new block.
They lived in a house by the sandlot and had the world's greatest tree house, because their dad was a contractor.
My real dad died when I was just a little kid. My mom married Bill a year before we moved to the neighborhood.
At the time, he and I were still getting used to each other.
Everyone knew Benny was different.
Even though he seemed like a regular guy, he wasn't. Benny was special, and he was loyal.

When they'd all tried out for youth league, they'd all made it. But when they found out they'd have to play on different teams, Benny told 'em that if they couldn't play together, they shouldn't play at all. So, they stayed together.
So, the only person that ever felt sorry for me 'cause I was such a weenie was Benjamin Franklin Rodriguez.
Even though neither of us knew it at the time, we were connected. Like I had been born for just that one moment, when I would perform the world's all-
Everyday, first thing, we'd all pick a card from what we called "The Dugout."
Because, when they went over, they vanished.

But, of all the things we ever did besides baseball, goin' to the pool was what he tolerated best. Even though none of us had ever seen a Playboy magazine - which we constantly lied about - we figured the pool was the next best thing to being there.
It wasn't the Pool Honeys like we said, 'cause if any one of them had come up to any one of us, we'd of peed our pants.
And one day, it became too much for Michael "Squints" Palledorous. And he did the most desperate thing any of us had ever seen.

Michael "Squints" Palledorous walked a little taller that day. And we had to tip our hats to him. He was lucky she hadn't beat the crap out of him. We wouldn't have blamed her. What he'd done was sneaky, rotten and low.
And cool.
Not another one among us would've ever, even for a million dollars, had the guts to put the move on the Lifeguard.
Besides The Great Bambino, who I still had no clue about, Benny had one living hero.
A guy that would break the stolen bases record that year that had stood for as many years as there were baseball's lost to The Beast.
Maury Wills became a hero for what he did.
There was only one nightgame a year.
We all knew Benny was different. We knew that he was gonna go on to bigger and better games.
Because everytime we stopped to watch the sky that night like regular kids, Benny was there to call us back.
For him, baseball wasn't just a game.
Once we got over trying to be big shots, we just stuck to what we could handle, and swore off the hard stuff forever.
And it happened alright.
It was salt in an open wound. Even my own mom, who was only a grown-up girl, knew who Babe Ruth was.
I was dead meat. I knew it. They knew it. We had thought that those cards Benny had gotten meant that something great was going to happen.
We had absolutely no idea what the hell we were gonna do. So things started primitively.
Yeah-Yeah grew two feet in our eyes after that. There was no stinkin' way any of us would've showed back up, if we'd loaded our drawers.
Yeah-Yeah did. He showed back up and got right to work, like nothing ever happened.
- Yeah-Yeah returns across the sandlot and goes up into the treehouse.
My life was over. Just as Bill had finally warmed up to me, and asked me to be the man of the house, I had to knock a priceless chunk of history into the clutches of a monster. Great.
It was weird that Benny said Babe Ruth was like the Hercules of baseball, and then The Beast's name turned out to be Hercules.
It was also strange that Mr. Mertle had a Murderers' Row ball to replace the one signed by The Babe.
That was the last summer that we all got to play together.
But it would stay with us forever.
After Benny pickled the Beast, his reputation spread all over town. From then on he was known as Benny "The Juet" Rodriguez.
The nickname stuck with him the rest of his life.
hits a homerun. Settles into his signature, locomotive basepath chug.
Now don't go peeing your pants or nuthin', I'm just here to give ya a hand.
- of Krash and a hundred other dopey names. Forget about that, we ain't got much time. I'm here 'cause you're in some kinda pickle, right?
A baseball with my John Hancock on it went over a fence, and you can't get it back. Right?
Then just hop over there and get it.

Is that a fact? Listen to me, kid.
Everybody gets one chance to do something great. Most people either never take the chance 'cause they're too scared, or they don't recognize it when it spits on their shoes.
This is your "big chance," and ya shouldn't let it go by.
Remember those cards you got the other day?
What're the odds on that?
You're the one with the rubba legs.

Well, you think I knew I was gonna swat that?
Not a chance. Matter of fact, all the way down to first I kept sayin' to myself, "you lucky bum."

who're already packing up in slumped dejection.

one by one, stop foolin' around. Chest deep in the shallow end, they're a detached and frozen pocket of leering dopes.
lines the edge of the deep section.
and a bunch of kids at the infield railing. Autograph signing.

playing hard beneath them. Snap throws. Basket catches.
